ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much! It was incredibly special to be able to learn about elements of Tuscan culture and history and then be able to visit them in real life. I learned so much about italian history and culture.
I learned a lot more about the culture of Tuscany and the important people and places that came from it.
I learned a lot about Tuscan culture, history, and Italian literature!
tuscany history and culture
You learn a lot about Tuscany and Tuscany history, especially Siena.
History of Italy specifically of Siena and Tuscany. Focused on Italian art and literature also.
History and culture of Tuscany. Also did some introductory readings of Italian authors in the western canon like Dante, Petrarch, and Boccaccio.

The course served perfectly to introduce me to Italian culture, history and literature. As a history major, I learned so much about Tuscany's rich art history and was able to draw parallels from the past to explain the current situation.

A very general overview of the history, art, and literature of Italy (focusing on Tuscany) from the late middle-ages to the present. A gentle introduction to what I imagine would be L5-level writing and presenting in Italian.
I developed an understanding of Italian history, art, and culture.

This course allowed me to learn more about the religious and literary figures important to Italian culture and towns. I was also able to learn more about the establishment and tales of towns such as Siena, San Gimignano, and Livorno.
I developed a new understanding of Tuscan culture and Sienese history.
I learned a lot about Tuscan culture and history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses! Simona is incredible.

Strength: Simona is an excellent prof, incredibly clear.  The language she uses with students is simple enough to be easily understood and yet challenging enough that you will learn more Italian by listening to her.  When the readings were difficult she did a great job helping us through it.  A lot of the city and museum visits were cool.

Weaknesses: some of the museum visits ran a little long, especially difficult when a lot of the buildings were not air conditioned.  I think the course could have benefited from a little more discussion of the Italian language and how it is a product of Tuscany (which I really wanted to learn about as someone with an amateur passion for linguistics).  A lecture on that can be swapped in place of the second visit to Lo Spedale or the synagogue in Siena.
There are a lot of class visits which I loved and think helped a lot.
very engaging class

The biggest strength is Simona and her in depth understanding of all the content. However there are a few important improvements that could be made. First, all of the guided tours are in Italian. I understand that this is necessary, but everyone I spoke to in the class was lost for many of the tours. Thus we stood there not understanding anything and wanting to know about the places we were at. It would be much better if Simona or someone with an understanding of learning the language would give us the tours, so they could teach us rather than talk at us. Would also be helpful to get info prior to the excursions so we can know the vocabulary. 
Secondly, I would love to see more diversity in what we learn. We learned a lot of history and literature, but not a lot of culture. I would like to see more information about music, more modern art, and theater.
It was interesting because we went on many field trips and Simona was always great at explaining the content. It was an opportunity to learn about Italy interactively.

Everything was great. However I didnt get as much out of the guided tours as I could because there would often be complex vocab that we had not learned before. Perhaps learning some of this vocab (e.g. things related to religious iconography, parts of a building) before the tours would be beneficial.

Much of the course involved going on very engaging field trips around Siena and Italy broadly. I loved the weekly critical reflections as a way to keep up with the content we learned and give your opinion. Class discussions also flowed amazingly and supplemented our Italian learning as well as deep reflections on texts we read or places we visited. I would have liked to read more Dante and focus more on the humanist writers, however, with so much to learn elsewhere and outside of class in a beautiful country like Italy, it was a very fair sacrifice.

Only weakness I would mention is that I don't think the readings were as well-utilized in class as they could have been. It often seemed like the readings were only there to check if we did the readings. Everything else was a strength.

This course is great. Simona chooses readings and lessons wonderfully, and I feel like we were able to get a pretty good understanding of the most important literature and art from Italy, and the cultural forces behind its creation. Field trips helped deepen understanding and I enjoyed the selected films. The course being conducted in Italian helped with my Italian language skills, and I thought the assignments were fair and the workload was very manageable. Sometimes the tour guides during field trips were very hard to understand, whether that be because of the speed at which they spoke or the use of unknown vocab words. I think it could be helpful if students are given a list of words that might be helpful to know for the trip. The tours that Simona conducted were very understandable and I learned so much interesting history from her.

I enjoyed the exploratory part of the course and visiting different monuments and towns. While understanding the tour guides was a little difficult in the beginning, I do believe that it helped us improve our abilities to listen and understand when locals would speak to us. The text that we read in class was difficult to understand, but I believe that the discussion that occurred in class helped break down and simplify the motives of the writers.
The course immerses students in Tuscan culture and history. The course could be improved by providing occasional quizzes to help students retain information throughout the semester.
I thought that the content was very interesting and the teacher was excellent but the long class period made it sometimes get difficult to stay engaged.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Simona is such an incredible instructor. It was also amazing being able to visit so many places and learn so much about italian culture while studying abroad.
In general the Siena program is a must.  This class is excellent and so integral to the immersion part.  You will learn a tremendous amount about Siena and Tuscany.
Yes!! It is perfect for practicing Italian conversation while learning more Italian culture and its not overly challenging if you put in the work.
yes - the professor was great
Absolutely it's a great way to explore the country and also learn the foundations of Italian culture.
Absolutely. Simona is the best and the whole intermediate Italian Siena program

If you're interested in History, literature, religion, or really any humanities subject field, this course will be a pleasure for you to engage in whilst learning the Italian language. Students with other focuses may find this course difficult, similar to the difficulty they'd encounter with a humanities course at Yale. I personally loved this course; it truly sparked my interest in art history, archeology (strangely, this isn't a focus), and Italian literature such as Dante especially.
Definitely.
Yes, definitely. I think it makes the entire trip to Italy more interesting because you are better able to understand the culture that you are experiencing.

I would recommend this course to another student due to its wide coverage of Tuscan culture and its ability to expose one to topics that they have never thought of before. I think that it did a great job touching on different sectors such as literature and art history.
I would highly recommend the course. The course requires a lot of engagement in conjunction with the language course, but it's fun and students do learn a lot from the course.
It's an excellent course on Tuscany and its culture and history and especially because of the immersion, it was easy to engage with the class topics out in our every day lives.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I have a great appreciation for Italian culture and hope to move here.

I will be completing the Italian certificate in my last two years at Yale, so having the leg-up of two months of speaking Italian with the locals is essential, and the culture course is also a credit towards the four for the certificate.  In general I do hope to spend time in Tuscany in the future.
I will use this knowledge of the language!
learn more italian
This course is essential for life in Siena because we need to understand the history of the places that we visit.
I hope to return to Italy again and explore even more!
This class made me want to take more classes on Renaissance literature, so Ill be able to apply my knowledge to those further classes

Next semester, I want to take an L5 course on the Inferno. Simona's interest and introductory instruction of Dante sparked my interest in the study of this writer, along with others. This course truly opened doors to my study of Italian literature and art history.
Definitely want to take a L5 class with Simona.

I now am able to understand some art that I see more deeply and recognize the effects that foundational Italian literature and philosophy have had on history and the present. I have been inspired to keep learning about art history, and I would love the opportunity to take more classes with Simona in the future to keep up with learning the Italian language.
Next time I go to Italy, I will already have many memories from my time in Siena. I will be able to also immerse myself in Italian literature and music at home.

extras.title: ITAL S235 01 - Tuscany: Past and Present
